Any bites?
Nibbles.
Keep throwing that line. A pat on the arm and he’s off to the bar where his double Seagrams is already being poured by ROY BAKER (60's), swe face that’s seen some miles -- like a broken down boxer.
A little eye opener, Kenny?
Breakfast of champions, Roy. Breakfast of champions. Wells raises his glass in his signature salute.  WELLS (CONT’D) To the mother lode. Wells pounds the whiskey and WE GO...
Wells sits at his “desk” -- the corner booth in the back the bar. Working one of the two phones on the table. He flicks the ash from his smoke into a half full ashtray.

(into phone) ..-It’s an outstanding opportunity, which is why I’m calling you personally. The geologic reports are encouraging and we’re taking a very aggressive position. Look, why don’t I give you a ring this afternoon and we'll see if there are any parcels left. Well, if you just give me... Click. Another one that got away. WELLS (CONT’D) You have a pleasant day... He hangs up the receiver and grabs his drink, a HAND stop before it reaches his lips.
11:15, Kenny.
Oh, Christ. He hops out of the booth. Maybe drinking all morning sudd not the best idea.

It’s a miracle.
A million bucks? Her looks says let’s not get carried away, but she says:
Two million. He drains his drink.
I‘1l come by for you after. We’1ll celebrate.
I’‘1l have my dancing shoes on. Down the bar a NICKEL SLOT MACHINE noisily pays out. They see this as a good sign.
I’ve got a good feeling about this. And he’s off. And WE GO:
TIGHT ON a PICTORIAL in Northern Prospector. Wells, in th reception of a local investment bank, flipping pages. Fli Flip. Checks his watch, looks at the receptionist, BEV.
Any idea how much longer, Bev?

Shouldn’t be too much longer now, Kenny. How you been?  6A. He makes the so-so gesture with his hand. Two bankers ent LLOYD STANTON (30's) and HENRY ANDREWS, even younger, in suits, with looks on their faces that say, “Let's get thi over with.” Stanton extends his hand.
Mr. Wells, I’m Lloyd Stanton. My colleague Henry Andrews. Wells puts on a smile and shakes hands.
Good to meet you.
Come on back.
Stanton and Andrews take seats at one end of the conferen table. Wells stands uncomfortably alone at the other end.
What can we do for you?
Aren't we waiting for Clive?
Mr. Coleman is tied up in a meeting.
No offense boys, but I was supposed to be meeting with Clive.

None taken. But, if you were supposed to be meeting with Clive you'd be meeting with Clive. That stung. Wells takes just a moment to recover. Sits. S a smile on his face and slides documents across the table

We're developing some very exciting properties that are spot-on for your investor profile: low buy-in with a sizable upside and the beautiful part is they’re all only twelve to eighteen months to cash positive. Stanton and Andrews listen impassively, scanning the docu
Manitoba?
We picked up an option on a skipped claim at auction.
It’s a ninety day option.
Yes, the window is narrow, but there’s an excellent shale formation that...
...-Natural Gas? Environmental impact’s gonna be a bitch. I don’t like the liability. What’s next? He dismissively flips the page, leaving Wells to quickly shift gears.

Eastern Utah. We’re sitting on a nice land-lease opportunity. The overburden is borax rich so there’s an immediate revenue source, but the real prize is in the granite under-shelf. Our studies point to rich chromium and nickel deposits.
There’s a pretty long chain of title on this claim. No payouts. What makes you think you’re gonna be luckier than all these others?
All under capitalized. Never got past development, none of them.
Under capitalized? I’m not sure under capitalized does your situation justice. Wells swallows down another helping of pride and pushes o
We've hit a down turn, yes, true enough, but...

.-.-Mr. Wells, Washoe has a practical value hovering just above zero. Your debt load is untenable and you come to us with raw land, no infrastructure, no fungible assets. You can’t possibly expect us to underwrite this.
I’m talking about a small offering here. If you’ll just look at the geo you'll see what I see, which is money. Stanton looks him in the eye. A beat.
Not our money. He closes the documents with an air of finality.
We can’t help you, Mr. Wells.
These are jackpot, gentlemen. You back away from these - these are career changing opportunities. Stanton rises from his chair.
If you'll excuse us.

I want to talk to Clive! Wells stands, his already red face flushing, every broken capillary showing like battle scars. WELLS (CONT’D) My father put Clive Coleman on the map. He built this goddamn bank!
You are not your father, Mr. Wells. Like a dagger. Wells stands stunned by the statement.
Bring us something we can sell and we'll talk.
These are good properties.
They’re crap, Wells. Played out hand- me-downs. I’d be embarrassed to even talk to my clients about them. Andrews... Stanton slides the documents across the table at Wells.  10.
Is there anything else? Wells gathers up his papers.

Yeah. Go fuck yourself. He grabs his bag and walks out with as much dignity as he can muster. Stanton watches him go. He knows he did his job, he kicke Wells's ass, but it doesn’t mean he has to feel good abou There but by the grace of God... Andrews, on the other ha is smiling, misreading his boss.
Not even noon and the guy reeks like a still.
Shut up, Andrews.
Wells on the street. Tracking with him. Walk of shame. Do slams. Leans back in his car seat. Trembling.
That had to be the worst day of my life. WE PULL IN CLOSE on Wells's face, panic rising in his eye

I'd lost my house and was living at Kay's. We were pretty close to losing that, too. PULL BACK TO REVEAL WE ARE...

A street of small tract homes. A nice little neighborhood forty years ago, now it feels a lot like the people who l here -- tired and in need of attention. It’s getting dark that moment the night and soul closes in.  11. INT. KAY’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - EVENING The place is small and reflects a woman’s touch, just the slightest bit girly. Everything worn, humble, but maintai On the counter, we see a mess of BILLS, mostly RED NOTICE Phone. Electric. Gas. Car. Wells sits on the edge of the talking on the phone, pitching for his very life.

...we’re looking at yields in the high six figures... Yes, that’s right. Kenny Wells. Washoe Mining. I spoke to your wife last week. A SERIES OF DISSOLVES. MORE WHISKEY -- as much spills on table as makes it into the glass. On the table, a pretty dent in the bottle. WELLS (CONT’D) ...I’m taking out of my personal holdings to cover demand... Could you hold on a sec, I’ve got to take this call... IT’S DARK NOW Wells is now slumped in an armchair. He muzzles the phone reaches for his drink.
Washoe Mining, the company my grandfather scratched out of the side of a Nevada mountain, that my father built into a real player. He drinks with a shaky hand. Steadies, and downs the rest

.--It only took me five years to run it into the ground. He’s blind drunk, struggling to get his mouth around the words. The fight has gone out of him... WELLS (CONT’D) If you could just let me know when a good time would be for us to sit down, I’m sure you would see... But that’s as far as he gets. The hum of the dead line. H sets the phone down, leans his head against the cold wind and closes his eyes. His breath fogs the glass instantly.
At the close of that day, Washoe was trading at four cents a share - if it was trading at all... He pulls a cig, last in the pack. Fire flares in his 11a. eyes.  12.
Hand, cigarette, fire, a deep inhale. Wells's eyes -- tur his attention back to the off-screen voice.
Rock bottom, as they say. Pun intended.

KAY’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - CONTINUOUS ..-who she finds passed out on the sofa. She takes in the prospectus papers all over the floor, the bottle of Seagrams, mostly drained. She stores her tips. Lights one of Kenny’s cigarettes. Po drink. Puts on some music. Through thin curtains sees a neighbor dragging a trash can around the side of the hous Kay flops back on the couch next to Wells. He realizes sh home and sorta half sits up.
Oh Kay. What are we gonna do? Kay?
Just shush... And he sags against her, head on her shoulder.
What are we gonna do?

We'll get by, baby. We always do.  13. His eyes have eased shut. Which she looks sideways and se She sighs, leans her head back, takes a sharp pull on her and blows smoke up at the ceiling. And we look down at th tableau through the smoke.

I had a half a gallon of Seagrams in me. I should’ve been dead. But I wasn’t. Instead, what happened was I had a dream. I mean, literally. I had a dream. Camera pushes down, tightening on Wells... WELLS (V.O.)(CONT’D) Indonesia... Closing on Wells's sleeping eyes. And suddenly WE ARE --

WE SOAR above the jungle canopy, diving down through the foliage, emerging atop a jagged ridge overlooking -- A PRISTINE JUNGLE VALLEY. A shimmering river winds throug Everything is bathed in BRILLIANT GOLDEN LIGHT, breathtak
I met Mike Acosta years earlier. That was the first time. I still hada little money then and Indonesia was booming. I was looking for a way to get in...
Boots splashing through a shallow creek. A HAND scoops in shallow moving water and pulls up a fistful of silt. A fi silhouetted in jungle.

..-Back then, if you were aiming to put a hole in the ground in Indonesia, you wanted Mike Acosta telling you where to dig. TIGHT ON miners carrying bags of ore up wooden ladders. WELLS (V.O.) (CONT’D) He was what they called a “River Walker.” A hands-on geologist. The real deal: Oxford college, MIT.  13A. And AT THE TOP FIND MIKE ACOSTA, 30's, giving orders, squinting against the light, something regal in his beari WELLS (V.O.) (CONT’D) Mom was Venezuelan. Dad, English. Left when he was little. That’s always tough.  14.

Diaphanously clad HOSTESSES lounge with businessmen. Racy hell for a Muslim country. Everyone sweating cheap booze. Acosta holds court at a corner table. Prospectors hang on every word. Chief among them Kenny Wells.

He’d just discovered the largest copper strike in Southeast Asia and everyone wanted a piece of him. And for a half-English guy, his teeth weren’t all that messed up. Acosta dumps an ashtray on the table, scatters the conten using ashes and burning embers to illustrate his point.

You got the Nazca plate off South America, the Pacific plate, Juan de Fuca, North American, South American. You've got trenches, fissures and fault lines - Aleutian, Marianas, Tonga - the plates rubbing and grinding up on each other - six trillion kilobars of pressure, ten thousand degrees Celsius kicking up geothermic hot spots all along the Pacific Rim. He takes them all in with a rogue’s smile... An INDONESIA GIRL, who understands no English, hangs on his every word ACOSTA (CONT’D) Pressure, heat and time. And there’s no better cooker than right here. Is he talking about geology now, or where his hand is res on the back of the thigh of the Indonesian girl?  15.
He called it the “Ring of Fire” theory. And he definitely had everyone's attention.
It’s how I found the copper, and it’s why I’1l find the gold. Find Wells nodding along, smitten.
I was too small-time to really get his ear, but I kept tabs on him... And then I had the dream.
INT. KAY’S HOUSE - VARIOUS - MORNING

Still drunk, Wells digs through junk piled in a disused r that houses an old broken down jacuzzi. An empty pool out in a concrete yard. He searches a milk crate with items f long ago move. Finds an old business card -- MICHAEL ACOS

Okay, okay. Here we go. Now he moves to a dresser, a JEWELRY BOX sits on top. A g to the sleeping Kay. And he opens the box. He pulls out a ANTIQUE PAVE DIAMOND AND GOLD LADIES PENDANT WATCH. Kay stirs and Wells slips the watch into his pocket.
(sleepy) You're up early. He gives her a kiss goodbye which turns into a real kiss she pulls him down.
You wanna talk about yesterday?
I’ve got a plan. I’ve gotta go.
Kenny, listen. Carl had an idea...
Carl? American Home Carl?  15aA.
He said he could get you on, for a while, if you wanted.
I... I don’t know... I’m not really --
I bought everything you’re selling and I’m no fool. You could sell ice to Eskimos.
I don’t know, babe. Let me get back from this trip.

It'd be temporary. Just til the market turns. (a real proposal) We could fool around in the warehouse. 15A.  16. A moment as he looks at her. All sorts of things going on there. It’s love. And the certainty she’s with him. Alway
I'll be back soon, a week at most. If it doesn’t pan out, I'll talk to Carl.
Wait. What? Back from where? And he’s gone. Kay gets up, mystified, about to go after when she sees the open jewelry box. Her watch is gone.
Dammit, Kenny--!
A GOLD ROLEX PRESIDENTIAL sliding off a wrist. It’s place a counter, followed by a diamond pinky ring, sapphire cuf links and Kay’s pendant watch. A ROLL OF CASH changes hands.
I didn't think twice. I was on my way.
Pushing as Wells exits, counting his money, wiping frame.  17.
It was like I was being called. It was the gold calling. I know that sounds crazy, but if you knew that feeling... If you knew... As a PASSENGER JET TAKES OFF just over the pawn shop.

The city sparkles -- it’s a collision of tradition and technology; tall towers and shanty towns; soaring wealth crushing poverty. There’s something electric about it. Super: JAKARTA, INDONESIA WE FIND Wells entering one of the finest hotels in the wo
Lavish. Everything the name implies. Wells on a house pho One cigarette smolders in an ashtray as he lights another

Yeah, Mike, it’s Kenny Wells. I’m in the lobby of the Jakarta Palace... leaving another message. We must have gotten our wires crossed about the time. Look, I have a few other meetings, I'll try and move things around. Give me a jingle, okay? He hangs up. He checks where his watch would be. Asks a passing waiter the time. Still no Acosta. He drinks. Drag his smoke and burning ash falls on his jacket, making a h WELLS (CONT’D) Goddammit. He starts to furiously brush it off when he hears --
Wells? And there’s ACOSTA. Calm and confident and smiling.
Hey, Mike! Thanks for coming. It’s good to see you again. Does Acosta remember him? Maybe. A hustler trying his bes to look needy. Disapproving eyes from around the clubby l  18.
I know a local place, a bit more color, if you know what I mean.
What, they’re not pouring here? Then Acosta remarks something in Indonesian and a lobby c snaps obsequiously, ushers them toward the lounge. WELLS (CONT’D) Now you’re talking, Mike.
A discreet bar cart navigates a lounge area now packed wi Jakarta’s international business elite.

.--So this salesman goes up to a house and knocks on the front door. It's opened by a ten year-old boy who has a lighted cigar in one hand, a glass of whiskey in the other and a Penthouse magazine tucked under his arm. Salesman: "Hello son. Is your mom or dad home?” The little boy: "What the fuck do you think?" Wells laughs loud. A BARMAN mixes their drinks. Acosta ta his, glances at his watch.
So, Kenny, what are we talking about?
Ring of fire, Mike. Ring of fire. Acosta gives a little laugh.
You're playing my greatest hits, now. Fire’s gone out of that one.
What are you talking about?  19.
Ring of fire hasn’t been proven. It’s the opinion of my fellow esteemed geologists that the whole thing is, quoting here, a crock of shit. Wells takes a moment, the wheels turning, then...
Well, what the hell? You called it wrong, what are you gonna do? Acosta shoots a look.
In this game there is no right or wrong, there’s only hits and misses.
So, you still think you’re right?
I don’t think I’m right. I know I’m right. There’s gold here.
I’m happy you said that, Mike. I truly am. I believe you.
I hate to dash your hopes, but don’t you think others have come along before you, with the same thought and, from the looks of it, deeper pockets?

Ring of fire is real. I knew it the minute I heard it. It was like a lightning strike. I never forgot it. Acosta laughs. He can’t help it. WELLS (CONT’D) Go ahead and laugh. I’m used to it. But hear this, I don’t just believe, I know.
No one will back me on this one. Wells mixes them both two more strong ones.
I will. I’11 get the money.  20.
You look like you had to rob someone to get here.
Tell me where you want to dig, Mike, and I’1l make sure the bills are paid.
You roll in here like we’re old pals? I’m a mirage, mate. You know jack shit about who I am.

You know it’s out there. I can see it in your eyes. You still believe. As Wells says this, we can see Acosta start to believe, m for the first time in a while. WELLS (CONT’D) I get it. I was born on the side of a mountain, too. My father scraped everything he had out of the rocks. He died with dirt under his fingernails. I intend to do the same. Acosta just might be wavering. Wells won’t let him get aw WELLS (CONT’D) This business wrote me off years ago, and maybe you’re not running a hot hand... Let’s prove ‘em wrong. Prove all of them wrong. And you know why? ‘Cause Ring of Fire is right. Tell me I’m crazy, I’1ll be on the next plane. Acosta is inscrutable. Wells waits, sweating. Finally:
You're crazy. Acosta rises from the table. He tosses cash down and brus past, leaving Wells like a raft with a hole in it.
Do you have a hat? DISCOVER Acosta has stopped behind Wells with a kind of t is the dumbest thing I'll ever do expression.
Yeah, I got a hat.  21. But Wells is starting to smile.
Good. I’m taking you upriver.
What river is that, Mike?
The only one that matters. Acosta walks out. Wells drains his drink. And WE GO...

A fishing village on market day. Talking birds, snake gaz and WELLS, weekend sporty, exiting a cab. The DRIVER yell points toward the river. Everyone wants to sell him somet He sees Acosta waiting by a traditional freighter canoe w the long-shaft outboard. The boatman, OBB, smokes a cigar
You're late. This is Obb. Wells eyes the boat warily.
That thing gonna make it?
Let’s hope so. (messing with him) Ever seen a Borneo pit viper?
Well I tell you, Mikey, I feel like I’ve met a few --
Drop out of the trees. Good swimmers, no bigger than this... (hands 12 inches apart) But if one gets you, find a phone, call your loved ones. Wells looks around. A few native faces. Huts. No phones.
(re: their boat) I went on the exact same thing once at Weeky-Watchee. Wells hops on the freighter canoe, rocking the shit out o  22.
Obb pulls away from the pier. Wells watches “civilization disappear behind a bend. And suddenly DAYAK TRIBESMEN pan for gold. In 300 yards, they’ve gone 5000 years back in t
The Dayak have been panning this river for thousands of years. That’s how it got it’s name, “Daya Kensana.” Acosta lets that hang there, like a tease.
Daya Kensana?
The word, Daya, actually means upstream... Kensana means gold. Wells can’t contain his smile.
Upstream Gold?
That’s its name.
You gotta be shittin’ me. If I had invented it, I wouldn’t have had the balls to name it that.

Natives pass in a canoe going the other way; wildlife alo the shore; ANGLES from shore, poo rafts next to clothes washing next to teeth brushing. Wells staring. A snake dr and swims through the water. Wells coolly lights a cigare RISE UP TO SEE the freighter canoe tiny with a white wake river golden in color, bisecting an endless green canopy. Wells POVs. Sun and jet lag. The steady buzz of the prop. Peering from under his hat, water rolling by. His eyes fi it, then shut. Then Acosta is shaking him awake. River narrower and darker under overhanging trees.  23.
The boatman pulls up at a muddy bank. A faint trail goes into jungle. Acosta hops ashore and Wells follows.
So, listen... the Dayak are warrior people. Probably best known for Ngayau... headhunting.
What the fuck?

They believe all of a man’s power is centered in his head. So they take the head. Doesn’t happen much anymore, but they're probably around thinking we’re traders or someone’s mother-in-law. Suddenly Wells freezes. There are FACES in the leaves, watching them. Then Wells realizes Acosta has vanished up dense trail. Wells nearly runs after him. Acosta stands. He has attached a heavy coconut to the end bamboo stick. He tests its weight on the ground. THUMP. T sets out again. Thump Thump Thump.
Okay, I’1ll bite. What is that?
It makes the king cobras and pythons think an elephant is coming. Wells watches every footfall.
Light filters from high in the canopy. THUMP THUMP THUMP. coconut vibrates the earth. Wells follows, drenched in sw He stops.
Getting a world-class case of crotch rot back here. (continues, then) Jesus... How long..?
Forty million years. For the geology to cook. Then we come along and take it.
I meant --

I know what you meant, Wells. But imagine being asked to give up something you've been hoarding for 40 million years? This jungle will test you, Wells. Hold you up, weigh you, and decide your worth within an ounce.
Do you always talk like this? Like a book on tape.
I suppose I do. Do you listen to books on tape, Wells? Ken Fol-let... Louis L'Amour... Ed-gar Rice Bur-roughs? He’s really made a meal of those pulp names.
Where are we going, Acosta? A no look point back over his shoulder --
Up. I want to show you something.
Up? How far up?  24A.
Six, seven miles tops. Watch your step. Wells looks up. If there’s a way, only Acosta can see it.  25.
Acosta emerges from the foliage into a clearing. Wells struggles up after -- Acosta stands on the edge, staring out like a man who’s c home. Wells is bent over, sucking air, drowning in sweat.

Take a look. Wells looks out and is instantly spellbound -- it’s JUST HIS DREAM. GOLDEN LIGHT sparkles over a pristine valley. KENSANA RIVER snaking around, smoke from a small village the river far in the distance.
My God, it’s just like my dream.

There have been a few folks up here tapping over the years but they’ve all focused on the foothills far to the south, drawn by the basalt overlay. He points to an area on the opposite side of the valley. ACOSTA (CONT’D) What interests me is the other way, on the east bank, up from the river. That small depression, like a giant left a footprint walking away. Far away we see limestone features we will recognize from “Washoe site.” True excitement in Acosta’s voice -- ACOSTA (CONT’D) Those limestone structures are 300 million years old, the pale color comes from skeletons of tiny sea creatures. But the placer gold I’ve recovered there is much older. Something happened there, Wells. Something hot and angry. That’s where we'll find the tasty bits. But Wells is barely listening. He’s transfixed.
My dream... It’s out there...  26.
Damn right it is. Two men together, staring out at their destiny, and WE GO

A small village on the river. A vendor scoops rice onto f leaves, grilling some kind of meat over an open fire. He the two portions up on a flat board. Wells goes for his wallet. Acosta stops him, producing a pouch. He removes a pinch of GOLD DUST, sprinkles it on a scale on the vendor’s cart.

Coin of the realm around here. (beat) When you think about it, Gold is utterly useless. Copper, Iron, Beryllium, Palladium, Bismuth, these are metals you can do something with. But the one that’s good for nothing is the one that everybody wants. Does have a quality though. When you hold it in your hand, it does something to you. Weights are adjusted, a little more dust -- no one can ta their eyes off the sparkling gold.
Like get you to spend your whole life looking for it.

.»+.so the lease is currently held by a Brazilian company. Acosta sits comfortably, eating. Wells searches his pocke finds a couple of mini-bar bottles of scotch, and a packe airplane peanuts. Offers one of the bottles to Acosta.
Only chance you got of surviving what’s in that bowl of microbes.
...-They’re looking to unload it cheap - getting buried on some Kazakh venture. Wells finds some peanuts from the plane. Eats them.  27.
You know, Mikey, I’m starting to love how you talk. And the first thing I’m gonna do is move some paper.
None of the big guys will touch us. In Wells we see a touch of the old confidence returning.

You want to raise money from the big boys, from Harvard endowment or some pension fund, I am not your guy. But the little guys, the guys you’ve never heard of... those are my guys. How much do we need?
Seven, seven-fifty to start. Ouch... Wells takes a beat to re-focus.
But how much are we gonna need?
It’s not just the lease. We must first procure a permit, which in Indonesia means lining pockets. There are capital costs, too. Equipment. You don’t just do this with a couple shovels and a pick-axe.

I‘’1l get the money. Whatever it takes. Wells is about to wipe his face with his NAPKIN, but has sudden idea. He pulls out a pen and quickly scribbles something down on it then slides the napkin over to Acost
What’s this?
A contract. Read it. Sign it. Acosta looks over what Wells has written on the napkin. T share a look -- a moment. WE DON’T SEE WHAT’S ON THE NAPK
Fair enough.  28.
We got a deal? Acosta signs and sticks his hand out to Wells. They shake
Deal.

For the first time in my life, I was selling something I believed in. I could feel it in my bones. Wells up, remembering the energy. Reveal more of the spac pastiche of several eras, kind of a luxury camp mixed wit whorehouse. WELLS (CONT’D) Any real salesman will tell you...

Mr. Wells, please sit down. The voice belongs to PAUL JENNINGS, early 40s, buttoned-d shirt, conservative suit, but a fun tie that was probably gift. A tape recorder is on the table. Two other men, BAN and LEVINE, both 30's, skeptical, watch as Wells takes hi seat again.
...If you believe it, you can sure as shit sell it.
(braying into the phone) Hell yeah it’s risky... Bobby Burns standing mid-pitch.
I’m being straight here. But hey, no risk, no reward, right? It’s the usual crowd, but the mood is electric. Everyone’ working the phones, telling versions of the same story.
Acosta! Largest copper strike in history. Yeah, that guy. We got him --  29.
Platinum resume. Pla-ti-num. Oxford. MIT. That’s right: The Copper King --
Kin-sana. Indonesia. It literally means River of Gold. No, I’m not fucking kidding. Camera finding Wells AT THE BAR with his own phone, takin snippets of the phone pitches.

(into phone) It’s a 20k minimum buy-in and shares are flying off the shelf. Kay, passing with a tray of drinks, as Kenny tries to pul over. She shrugs out of his grasp and continues on. WELLS (CONT’D) Babe, this is fucking crazy --
Going like hotcakes. Hotcakes! Connie covering the mouthpiece, interrupts over --
I’m batting 500. BabeFuckingRuth. Every other call, Kenny.

Keep throwing the line. (into phone) The best. What’d I tell you? The best. (calling to Kay) Babe, shine those dancing shoes, get ‘em ready -- She flips him off. It’s not a forever anger, but she’s an
We don’t even have the exploration rights. What are they selling?
They’re selling the story, Mike. And right now, the story is you. Hey, speaking of which, what are you doing?  29A.
I’m down in Kupang City, looking at coring equipment.  30.
(yelling to the guys) Acosta’s in Kupang City looking at coring equipment. The sales pitch shifts, Kupang City. Special coring equip
(into phone) Coring rigs will come from Kupang City. I'll put you down for 20. Two shares. You got it.
(into phone) You're magic. And as WE LOOK over this makeshift trading floor in full action, the SOUND OF KEYS BEING PUNCHED rises above the d sales chatter -- TAPE PRINTOUT SCROLLING, and WE ARE...

Bobby Burns bangs figures into an ADDING MACHINE. Wells circles. It’s been a long day, everyone’s exhausted. Burn scrolls the tape, tears it off with a flourish. Passes it Wells, who reads, swallows hard, then delivers the number
(into phone) Two hundred sixty seven thousand, four hundred and thirty-four dollars. Over the phone, there’s SILENCE.
Acosta checks out new equipment while on a portable phone
(into phone) Not exactly the number I had in mind. Realize Acosta is now looking at the USED EQUIPMENT YARD.
Acosta stands looking up at rusting industrial dinosaurs against the endless blue sky.
I might be able to borrow a little bit against it. (beat) (MORE)
No. Truth. That's it for now. Can you make it work?
That’ll get us the permit, a few holes. If we work fast and get lucky, who knows...
Get us a little good news and we'll raise more money. Suddenly hear some DUDES AT A FOOSBALL TABLE loudly ARGUI over PAC-10 football, drowning out Wells.
You work out of a bar, Wells?

Keeping a lid on expenses, Mike. Makin’ the dollar holler. Acosta hanging up, wondering just what he’s gotten himsel into. He examines a well-used drill, speaks Bahasa with t mining equipment salesman, haggling. INT. KAY’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - NIGHT A suitcase on the bed. Wells sorta packing, a haphazard undertaking under the best of circumstances. He takes a d Surveys the possibilities.
Which tie? This one or this one? Reveal Kay behind him, drink in hand.
I want my watch back.
First off, it’s your mother’s and second you’re gonna get it back.
It was my mother’s until she gave it to me.  32-32A.
I gotta bring my good shoes, where are my good shoes?
Look under the bed. I don’t like to see my stuff up in pawns, Kenny. You know I’m sensitive to it. He gets down to look under the bed. See his ass sticking
We always talk about our dreams, about the ranch, clean air, big views, our place above it all. That’s what I’m doin’, getting us out of this shitbox.
I don’t mind this shitbox. He’s back up with the shoes.
See, right there, that’s what I love -- you're like one of those booster rockets that helps us get up to the stars. Stands back with the shoes. He wiggles the shoes. WELLS (CONT’D) Too much?
What the fuck, Kenny?
We figure shit out together, Kenny. Through thick and fuckin’ thin. If you needed my watch, I'd give it to you.

I know, babe. I‘’1l be back soon, I promise. He starts off... Then pauses like he remembers one last t WELLS (CONT’D) Oh, here -- why don’t you time me? He dangles her mother’s watch. Turns, smiling. She smiles too. Love rushes in, overflows.  32-32AA.
Wear the blue tie. It brings out your eyes.  33. As we PRE-LAP a CALL TO PRAYER --
Crossing river traffic reveals a luxury hotel amid minare Super: JAKARTA, INDONESIA
Acosta goes over paperwork, shaved, hair groomed, transfo Wells, adjusting his blue tie, comes out of the bathroom.
What’s that smell?
I dropped a goose.  33A.
And are you wearing cologne?
Yeah, why? You getting turned on?  34.

Listen to me: we have one shot at this. He’s the Minister of The Interior of Indonesia. If he doesn't like us for any reason, we’re done. Never put your hands on your hips. Crossing your arms is considered aggressive. And cologne, here, is an insult.
You get a whiff of some of the folks around here? I might suggest changing the national cologne policy.
We get the deal. We don’t insult. We don’t talk. We listen, we get our permit and we get out. Are we clear?
«.-yeah. Got it.
Now go wash it off. Wells stands there for a moment like a humiliated child. goes back into the bathroom. Off Acosta, WE GO:
A formal room with a Chinese theme. Seated at the table i MINISTER OF MINING. A cadre of security and yes-men flank The Minister speaks with a cultured Indonesian accent.

.-.I have reviewed your permit request for the Kensana property... As a waiter pours hot liquid into small bowls at each set we find Wells perspiring in his bad suit. He picks up his and starts to sip his “tea.” Acosta clears his throat -- sees the Minister dipping his fingers into his bowl.
(to Acosta) There is a conspicuous lack of documentation.
Hey, we've got the paperwork -- The Minister ignores him as Acosta jumps in.  34aA.
Yes, excellency. We have reports from previous attempts, but judged it best not to waste your valuable time. The Minister accepts this, but still ignores Wells.
(beat, to Acosta) What makes you think you will find what others before you could not?
They were looking in the wrong place. The underlying geology is sound. GIANT PRAWNS are placed in front of them. Wells can’t hel  34A.
Hey, can I get a fork? The waiters don’t move. Acosta and the Minister ignore We  35.
There’s gold there, Excellency. And with your blessing, we will find it. A long beat. Wells gets uncomfortable. Realizes his arms crossed. Uncrosses them. And sells.
Mike really knows his stuff. There’s no one better... The Minister doesn’t even look at Wells, addressing Acost
As you know, our natural resources are a divine inheritance of all the people.
As is your capable stewardship, Excellency.
A heavy responsibility to be sure. Wells fidgets, then barks to a waiter --
Hey! Who’s a guy gotta bang to get a drink around here? Wells definitely has the Minister’s attention now.
I am a Muslim, sir. I do not drink.
I’m an American and I do. And last time I checked, I’m hosting this little shindig, so you might want to at least acknowledge I’m sitting here.
You are most definitely an American.
What’s that mean?
It's the belief that paying for lunch is a substitute for manners.  36.

You're right. And I apologize. I can see I’ve offended your delicate moral sensibilities. But I may have just the thing to help you get over it. And with that, he pulls out a THICK WAD OF CASH from his jacket, sets it down on the lazy Susan with a THUD. And t spins it -- the cash rotates around the large table towar Minister. The Minister stares at Wells with contempt. WELLS (CONT’D) Now that you mention it, I’ve been thinking of converting to Muslim.
That’s enough.
Even if we don’t find any gold, at least I still get the forty virgins--
Wells --!

I’m not greedy. I'll go half--twenty’s a windfall. Hell, if they’re really virgins, two would probably kill me. The cash slowly stops revolving. The Minister never looks it. He stands, throws down his napkin, and, entourage in sweeps imperiously from the restaurant. Acosta looks at Wells, his anger and disbelief palpable. he grabs up the cash and goes. Wells is alone, his face flushed with embarrassment. He sees a patron staring at h WELLS (CONT’D) What the fuck are you looking at? Wells pours himself a cup of tea, hand shaking as he drin Then he looks up and sees Acosta coming back. Wells stand about to apologize, but before he can speak -- CRACK! Acosta decks him. Wells falls backwards over the chair, hitting the floor. He looks up at Acosta standing over hi and, in a flash, recognizes just how much this matters to that much of his poise is a kind of cover. WELLS (CONT’D) You gonna tell me what happened? Wells gets up, brushing himself off. Acosta takes his tim  37. WELLS (CONT’D) I’m sorry, I couldn’t hear you.
He took the money. A smile spreads across Wells's face.
Of course he took the money. It’s money.

INFINITE JUNGLE in an anamorphic frame. Every leaf and bl of grass swaying in the wind. Then Acosta appears. This i Wells’s POV. He hurries to stay close. ACOSTA stops moving. He looks at Wells. He looks down. We approaches cautiously and also looks down. Acosta makes a in the soil. Now reveal a small army of NATIVE WORKERS waiting. A FORE shrieks and they break into motion... clearing the “giant footstep” for the first drill position at the “Washoe sit The sky is blue, dotted with white clouds; the river spar gold surrounded by the limestone cliffs. Tight shots of assembly, metal to metal. Acosta busy. Wel in his Loman suit slapping at Mosquitos, jungle pressing

A METAL SCAFFOLD lyrically sways above the grass, framed against the limestone cliffs. A break in the grass sudden reveals a WATER BUFFALO pulling the first drill. The drill is positioned. Jungle has been beaten back. A GIRL leads a goat out of a watchful crowd to the drill a Dayak “BORETN” waits. He murmurs prayers in his languag Then pulls a knife and, without hesitation or sentimental draws it across the goat’s neck -- AN ARM YANKS THE PULL-CORD on the drill, ROARING to life Panning NATIVE FACES to find WELLS as a gentle SUN SHOWER begins to rain down.  38.
See, ahh... That’s beautiful! The sky is blessing us. Acosta stares up at the sky with a different perspective.
Monsoon’s coming early.
Monsoon? CRACK! FLASHES OF LIGHTING. Wells's face realizing the seriousness. THUNDER RUMBLES. Rain falls harder. The DRIL SPINS down into the earth...
Vinyl spinning on a record player. Something lofty, obscu

A record player? Am I paying for that? But you can tell the whole thing makes Wells happy. He’s whiskey. The native foreman is there. And through the fla two distant drills glow under colored tarpaulins.

(re: the map) We're here. And now we step out ina semi-circular pattern. Six man crews, twelve hour shifts, around the clock. Tomorrow I'll start looking at core samples. We’ll send the most promising down river to the assay lab. When we get a hit we’ll drop holes to chart the contour of the vein.
Three foot ROCK CORES laid out in a wooden box... Pull ba reveal ten boxes... then twenty... Moving INSIDE --

Where a CIRCULAR SAW cuts a CORE. Wells watching Acosta examine a section, then toss it in a ROCK CRUSHER... The RUBBLE is then bagged in canvas sacks... which are closed sealed with HOT WAX... and finally stamped with a WASHOE THE CORE SAMPLES are carried in a long line through the v toward the river -- an Indonesian Salgado come to life. Wells and Acosta watch, all hopes and dreams in that line  39.
What do we do now? CAMERA RISES UP from the workers carrying the core sample the limestone cliffs and endless sky.
We wait. And we keep drilling.
Wells sprays himself liberally in bug spray, making a clo under the light. Almost immediately a bug bites his shoul
These bugs don’t give a fuck about this bug spray.

Wells, spatula in hand, watches mystery meat sizzle. He c and talks over his shoulder to Acosta who is working. WELLS (CONT’D) The guy who invented the hamburger was smart. But the guy who invented the cheeseburger... Genius. He begins serving them up. WELLS (CONT’D) Don’t ask where this meat came from. IT’S LATER They're both relaxing. Wells maybe a bit more relaxed. WELLS (CONT’D) Goddamn jungle. Nothing for 200 miles and look at us. Not so bad. Acosta takes in the night. Raises his cup in a salute to dark jungle all around. They both drink.
What’s the meaning of the tattoo?
It’s from a poem I read as a kid: (Acosta waits) The bird with no feet sleeps on the wind.  39aA.
You're full of mysteries, Wells. You really are.
You got any tattoos, Mike?
Only on the inside. Wells looks at him a beat, then looks out into the dark. sounds of drilling drift across the valley floor.
And a LONE MESSENGER running up the trail...

Wells meets him halfway, takes the ASSAY REPORT and tears open, reading. Even from a distance we can tell it’s bad A DRILL IS MOVED to a NEW POSITION. DRILL 2 IS MOVED. COR ARE CRUSHED and BAGGED. A CANOE LOADED WITH CORE SAMPLES motors away down the rising river. The rain is torrential MAIN TENT looks like it’s about to float away. Acosta mee Obb... Wells meeting him... Acosta...

Acosta and Wells, back to back, working. Acosta thinking geology, Wells looking at financials. Realize neither one looking at an unopened report on the table. Finally Acost tears it open, reads it. Passes it to Wells: INDO-KARTA LABORATORIES - ASSAY REPORT.

...-These things look worse every time we get one. Acosta stares steadily at his map, which shows an increas desperate spray of holes. WELLS (CONT’D) Thirty, 100 meter holes, Mike. Thirty. And what do we got? We got shit.
Remember what I told you about patience?  39aB.
Remember what I told you about money?
Yeah, it wasn’t a problem.  39A. Looks at the numbers. They don’t lie.
It’s a problem now.
I‘1l try something else. Move further up the seam. Drop 80 meter holes. Move faster.  40.
Do it. Wells suddenly shudders with a chill. Acosta looks at him WELLS (CONT’D) I’m fine.
You don’t look so good.

It’s ninety-eight degrees out and pissing rain. And all we're pulling up is dinosaur shit. How am I supposed to look? (beat) Jesus, I'm freezing. Wells starts to shake. Acosta puts a hand to Wells's head
You're burning up.

I’m fine. (off Acosta’s concern) I said, I’m fine. Wells forces himself to stand. He moves to Acosta's maps. WELLS (CONT’D) All right, where do we go next? But Wells has to sit. Off Acosta's concerned look WE GO..
That fucking rain. WORKERS, meager items held in plastic assemble in their tent. The FOREMAN speaks to his men.

We drilled our holes, assayed the cores and got nothing. Zero. We were nearly busted, out of money, out of time. Workers quitting. But, no way I was giving up, I was gonna find a way to keep going if it killed me.  41. One RIG IS SILENT. Wells struggles across the compound th the downpour to stop the men from leaving. He falls. Pick himself up. Waves his arms. Yells in a language they don’ speak. Even the buffalo is leaving. He slips again --

I picked up a bad case of malaria, which takes out something like a million people a year... And I was on the list. From the mud he sees the workers vanishing, a skeleton cr the remaining rig. He rolls on his back. And still the ra comes down.
Acosta enters. Doesn’t realize Wells is slumped in a chai the gloom.
The workers are leaving, Mike.
I know. I’ve got the new assay reports. Acosta lights a lantern, sees Wells. ACOSTA (CONT’D) Jesus. Get your ass in bed already. It’s an effort for Wells to speak, painful.
Talk to me.
There’s nothing to talk about. We’re not finding anything. Wells sags. The reality that he’s losing again sinking in Wells has another fit of chills. He’s half-delirious.
Maybe we’re pushing them too hard. Maybe we should take it easy, enjoy it a little bit.
Take it easy? Is that a Reno bumper sticker? The losers’ credo.  42.

Nah, man, it’s just life. Sometimes you just gotta take it easy... I’m freezing. Acosta helps him to his cot. Pulls the thin blanket over. WELLS (CONT’D) Maybe cut ‘em all in... offer ownership, share in the upside... The DISTANT WHINE of the last drill suddenly GOES QUIET. TIMELESS CACOPHONY of the jungle RISES. WELLS (CONT’D) I’m scared, Mike. Don’t let me die out here for nothing... Wells passes out into a feverish sleep. Acosta watches hi long time before reaching a decision.
Acosta steps into the empty, silent camp. Rain curtaining his hat. He sets out alone.

Acosta walking through the rainy jungle toward a village. natives in the limestone cliffs looking down. Acosta pass pond where people bathe and fill jugs with muddy water. AT THE LONGHOUSE there are DAYAK WOMEN on the porch. Acos has a few quiet words. One slowly stands, disappears thro the DARK OPENING. Acosta cannot see inside. It’s too dark remaining women look at him evenly. The “FOREMAN” appears obviously a LOCAL CHIEF.

(Dayak) What can I do to get you to return to work? We are running out of money, it’s true. But we’re close. I know it. A beat as the foreman considers Acosta. Then he gestures follow. The rising CRIES of a child can be heard.

Thrumming rain on the thatch and in half-gloom find a fev CHILD. Acosta watches as the mother tries to get him to t sip of water. Acosta kneels and passes his canteen to the mother. Urges her to pour clean water.  43.

He realized what they needed wasn’t stock options, but drinking water and antibiotics. And damned if he didn’t go to every little place every one of our people came from. Streams that had no name. All feeding the great Kensana river.
A skeptical Jennings observes Wells a moment.
And you believe this was sincere?
Absolutely. Mike’s half a native anyway. He was trying everything. And I was a mess. Malaria is no joke.
The monsoon continues, but Wells is oblivious, a shudderi chill wracking his body. Acosta watches this uneasily.
We need to get you out of here. I’m pulling the plug.
Not happening. Tell me the plan.
What they need... they need clean water, antibiotics... (reluctant) If we get filter systems up here, I think they'll come back. Wells looks up with dim eyes, a smile crossing his face.

I’ve got maybe eighteen hundred dollars of room left on the Visa. Five hundred on Diner’s Club. Use it all. Wells hot and dry. Acosta looks down at him. He doesn’t t Wells is gonna make it. He’s seen it before.

A break in the rain. Misty clouds circle limestone mounta  43A. Brown water in a micro filter as Acosta hangs it from a branch. Clear water flows out a hose. A child tastes the water, doesn’t like it. Several children laugh. In the river a mother sits with her baby on her lap.
As Acosta fills ANOTHER FILTER, reveal NATIVES finding go the stream. It almost mocks Acosta.
THE SAME LIMESTONE CLIFFS... ONLY NOW WE TILT DOWN and FI

text: Wells tossing and turning on the cot having his fever dre
I spent the next few weeks in a malarial haze. I should have been dead. The workers stayed. Mike kept it all going. And he kept me alive.
Acosta in the rain, turns and sees something that stops h

Did he manage to enjoy himself a little bit along the way..? A BEAUTIFUL NATIVE GIRL stares at Acosta through the rain It’s like they know each other. WELLS (V.O. How should I know? I was delirious. I do not recommend Malaria treated with a bunch of leaves.
Rain. And the sound of an IGNITING FLAME... FUMMM --! A B FLAME. And Wells in and out of consciousness to find a BO in their tent brewing a potion of herbs as Acosta watches
What is that?
No idea. But they say it works.
They don’t have electricity. Or socks. The Boretn brings a bamboo mug toward Wells.
Come on, get it down.  45. Wells chokes down the remedy.

Limestone cliffs and mist. Drills spinning, biting into e Clouds passing overhead. Men feeding pipe to the machine. Wells drenched in sweat, looking like death -- ACOSTA and FOREMAN load CORE SAMPLES onto a boat. DRILLS SPINNING, biting into the earth/WELLS TOSSING, TUR drenched as the FEVER FINALLY BREAKS. Obb brings another report. Acosta reads, betraying no emo FEVER DREAM: A RAFT FLOATING ON A GOLDEN RIVER... We’re drifting toward it as it goes around a bend... SOMETHING it... a BODY.. FUNERAL BIER. Closer... closer... it’s WEL
WELLS COMES TO -- surprised to be alive. Surprised it’s n raining. Realizes Acosta is right there looking at him.
What day is it?
No idea.
Month?
August. See this is a different month than Wells expected.
You been sitting here this whole time?
Let’s not get carried away. Wells now realizes Acosta has an assay report.
You gonna talk, or what?
We pulled seventeen more cores. He looks at Wells, unreadable.  45A.
What? What do they say? No good?  46.
Not good... Wells falls back. Acosta stands, a completely different l on his face, one of wonder -- ACOSTA (CONT’D) More in the vicinity of great. Wells looks up. A face that’s almost afraid to hope.
Don’t mess around, Mike.
Eighth of an ounce per ton. Wells scans the reports, rising to his feet.
Eighth of an ounce per... WHAT!!?? Acosta smiles -- Wells is in shock.
We've got a strike, Kenny. Wells smiles, laughs, screams!
We've got ourselves a gold mine!
That we do. Wells struggles up to his feet and joins Acosta best he c jumping up and down.
CAMERA DRIFTS outside to meet Wells who appears through t doorway as he YELLS TO THE HILLS --

head_text.subj: WE GOT A GODDAMN GOLD MINE --

text: Which ECHOES back to him from the cliffs --

head_text.subj: WE GOT A GODDAMN GOLD MINE MINE MINE

text: POP!!! Gold-leafed bottles in buckets. Champagne sprays f the bottle as Wells moves through the crowd at the bar, filling everyone's glasses.
That moment, there’s no way I could possibly describe the feeling. The regulars are all here, sharing in Wells's victory.
It’s amazing how a little gold dust can change everything. For better or worse, the ride had begun. And what a goddamn ride...

The place is vibrating! MUSIC OVER. Wells is with Bobby B and Connie and Nevins celebrating at the bar. Kay passing a round of drinks, the last one to Wells. Kenny looks at Kay; Kay looks at Kenny, deep into each ot a small moment of private understanding in passing that s it all. Then he turns to his guys:
To the best team in the business!
You're a stand up guy, Kenny.
To sharing the wealth.
To the mother lode! They clink glasses and drink deeply, "To the mother lode!
Kenny and Kay driving into the hills on a perfect afterno Fun and carefree, windows down, 70’s music on the radio.
Smell that? Smell that air? Mountain air. It’s a tonic.
Ah, so good. So good.  47A. They're singing along. Passing small family ranches.
Remember I told you Janice got promoted to run Truckee?
Mmm hmm. Good for her.

Well, Carl asked me if I’d like to be considered to take her place. Assistant Manager position. Outside the car as they go zipping past, music trailing, GHOST TOWN, faded signs and abandoned buildings... A dang sign reads, “MAGGIE'S CREEK... Pop -- “0” in spray paint.
That’s great, babe.
Everything's working out so great.  48. By way of agreement he rubs her thigh where the dress has ridden up. Sunlight filters through the trees above. Kay’ toes are painted eggshell blue.
You’re gonna be able to quit all of it if you want... Never work another day in your life. Blue skies coming.
Close your eyes. Wells drives down a country lane.
Wells stops, gets out and starts around the car.
(happy) Kenny Wells, what are you doing?

Eyes closed. No peeking. He opens Kay’s door, leads her a short distance. WELLS (CONT’D) Okay, now open ‘em. She opens her eyes. In her eyes something immense that mu comprehended. And for a moment we don’t see what she’s se and then we do:
The sweep of ranch land is epic. Prairie dogs hop away. E the distance the size of ants.
It’s beautiful.
It’s going to be our place, above it all, away from it all. Like we always wanted. We’ll put the house here. (MORE)
Fieldstone and oak. The kind that lasts forever. A big kitchen where I’m standing. And a great room with two fireplaces. He turns to look at Kay, to see if she’s going with it.
Can we afford this?
Almost, baby. Almost... Wells jogs a short distance away, still going...
Bedrooms here and here and here... And here... For the kids. Ah, come on, Kay... How many kids?
People usually start with one. They look at each other. It’s golden hour. Then she skips through the field toward him.
Kitchen should go the other way, Kenny. To get the morning light.
Wells laying it out for the boys: Burns, Connie, and Nevi

It’ll be straight commission to start, but this hook’s got meat on it. There’s money out there, so reel it in. They throw back the rest of what’s in their glasses. Well leans over and whispers to Bobby Burns. WELLS (CONT’D) This stock’s gonna start cooking. You sell a little here and there. Don’t wait. Think rainy day, Bobby boy.

The car doors are open, a great SONG plays on the radio. and Kay slow dance in the field as a glorious sunset fade  50. And PULLING BACK to find a BILLBOARD ON STILTS showing a “dream house.” As Kay and Wells slowly turn in the distan and the music is gently blown away across the fields.
Wells and Kay dancing in that way happy couples do, almos like they’re one person, her head melting against his che
Kenny... this is Walt Kealer. He publishes “The Gold Digger.”
We reach a half a million readers and they’d all love to know what you got cooking over there in Indonesia. You have a minute, I’1l buy you a drink. Kealer, a serious guy, and Burns both look at Kay.
(almost a whisper) No one dances like you. (to the world) He’s all yours, Walt.
Hell, I read the Gold Digger. Step over to my office, Walt. Wells signals for two drinks, leads Kealer to the booth.
They're saying you bring this in, you'll get the Golden Pickaxe. What do you say about that?
I say we probably just jinxed it.
How many ounces you guessing?
Millions of ounces, Walt. Millions. Kealer whistles. Makes a note.  50A.
Placer mining?
Hard rock. It ain’t amateur hour.
How's the infrastructure?  51.
Building it from the ground up. Wells sees Kay at the bar flirting/teasing with two regul Queen of the runway. He loves this.

I can explain -- you met him --
You are going to be fine, Bryan; you'll land on your feet. We stay on Woolf, in shock. The SOUND of a CHORUS of VOIC rises, and WE GO...

Bobby Burns and the boys singing along drunkenly to some As Wells enters carrying a heavy, taped-up roll of fabric a small, wrapped gift. Booze and music and cigarettes as turn and cheer him. But he’s looking for Kay.
Hey, Roy. Seen Kay around?
You didn’t hear?
Hear what, Roy?
She quit. Got the promotion out at the American Home -- Assistant Manager. Proud of her.

...In our top money news, a story that is being compared to David and Goliath, or maybe that’s Kenny and Goliath -- Kenny Wells that is...  106. As someone TURNS UP THE VOLUME on THE TV above the bar --
Washoe Mining has secured a deal with the Suharto government of Indonesia to retain control of their massive gold strike there, fending off a takeover by Newport Holdings.
Kicking Hancock’s ass -- More CHEERS. WELLS is the center of attention.
Washoe shares are soaring on the news. As CLIVE Coleman spots Wells. Wells sees Clive as he approaches. Whatever he’s here for, it looks serious.
Got a minute? Wells steps out with Clive.
Strip plazas, dollar stores, pawn shops. And the first st the sky, the Northern Star. Or a planet. One of them.
I just got a call. Wells freezes. Clive enjoys the moment. Giving away nothi
The National Association of Prospectors is gonna honor you with the Golden Pickaxe.
Are you shitting me?
You are officially the best miner in the world. And somewhere I’m sure your dad is smiling. There, outside The Three Greenhorns Bar, Kenny Wells has finally been accepted on terms he cares about.
Well if he’s not smiling, I’1l smile for the both of us.  107. He can’t speak any more. Too overcome by the moment. And he realizes where he’s gotta go --

The Caddy pulls up. Wells gets out. Opens the trunk. Gets big roll of gift fabric he bought in Indo. He’s happy. A peace offering in hand. Starts forward, the stops. He stares, his face falling. He sees --
Wearing her own clothes, a manager now, smiling at someth her boss is saying. She rests a hand on his arm --
THE ROLL OF FABRIC HITS THE FRONT DOOR and drops to the s Then the wrapped gift hits the door and drops. Wells back in his car. Door SLAMS. Car CAREENS AWAY, bare breaking around a distant turn.
EXT./INT. HARRAH’S HOTEL AND CASINO - RENO, NEVADA - DUSK
The Caddy rolls up under the awning at Harrah’s. An unctu MANAGER welcomes Wells personally.
Welcome to Harrah’s Reno, Mr. Wells.
Thank you very much... Carissa.
We have you in the Prospector Suite, which has a wonderful view of the mountains. Will you need help with your bags?
Oh, yeah. He looks back at the Caddy as the luggage trolley passes.  108.
The Prospector Suite has a lovely view of the mountains, Sir.
I’1ll take it.
Will you need help with your bags?
Oh, yeah.

The boxes he took from Kay’s. Rodeo clown ashtray. A few childhood pictures. Young Kenny holding a string of bass. Grandfather on a side of a mountain. His father standing to a new Caddy, looking for all the world like Wells. There’s a KNOCK at the door of the suite. Wells opens it find MIKE ACOSTA standing there.
I didn’t think you could make it.
(pure Wells) Who you talking to, Wells? (beat) Besides, you'll definitely need help with your tie.
Gold fixtures everywhere. Acosta sitting on a counter wat Wells wrestle with the bow tie.

I’m nervous. And the bow tie does present a mystery. WELLS (CONT’D) A thousand monkeys, a thousand years... Okay, hotshot... Acosta quickly ties the tie. Adjusts it. And now we see a changed Wells. He looks good. Catches himself in the mirr Acosta catches the same reflection. Wells pulls cards from his jacket. Looks at Acosta. A tru friend is the one you feel comfortable practicing this ki speech in front of.  109. WELLS (CONT’D) My great granddad came out here on a wagon. He had a horse and two mules... (to Acosta) Too much?
No, man. It’s good.
Mountains in the distance. INT. HARRAH’S HOTEL AND CASINO - BALLROOM - NIGHT
Wells at his table with Acosta, Bobby Burns, Stanton, Cli Connie, Nevins. He’s quiet. This means a lot him.
Kenny, you’re a star, boy. Don’t sweat it. I mean really, don’t sweat. He’s sweating. Someone passes him a napkin.

It’s been a long night and I’m sure you will soon hit the tables here at Harrah's Reno and make it a lot longer night. And hit those tables people... it’s why Verna makes the rooms so reasonable. Laughter around the room. A few big firms have tables. An lots of smaller players. It’s everyone’s night.

They do accept gold for bar tabs... (laughter) Now we come to our last honor, the 1988 Golden Pickaxe for “Prospector Of The Year,” which goes to our own Kenny Wells! Get up here, Kenny--! Wells rises and makes his way, showered with applause and FLASHING cameras. The crowd rises, saluting Wells, saluti that part of themselves that hangs on, refuses to give up Wells cradles the Golden Pickaxe statue, which is exactly it sounds, a golden pickaxe. He stares out, savoring his moment. Then holds it up as flashbulbs flash. Pulls his speech from his pocket. Looks out at faces, lau faces, no one taking this quite so seriously.  110.
Every last one of us who calls the great state of Nevada home arrived here with a dream.
(yelling out) Drinks on Kenny. Laughter. And AT WELLS'S TABLE --
Great state of Nevada? He sees Kay. He smiles. Realizes it’s not her.

...That was my great granddad who came out here on a wagon. Had a horse and two mules when they finally stopped moving and said this was the place, he was only about forty miles from right here. At the back of the room, ACOSTA IS LEAVING. He pauses and turns to Wells. A nod of respect and congratulations pass unspoken between them. And then ACOSTA IS GONE. Wells looks at the statue. WELLS (CONT’D) What is a prospector? (the crowd groans) No, I’m serious. It’s someone who believes it’s out there. Who wakes up every morning and somehow believes. Again and again. It’s not there. Standing at the edge of a desert, watching the sun rise and something in him says, “it’s that way, just walk.” FLASH, FLASH, FLASH! Wells walks the center aisle, drowne flashing light and glorious adoration. Everyone’s reachin to shake his hand.

And the sun is higher and it’s getting hot and nobody else sees anything. And everyone else wants to turn back... And then IT’S LATER and EVERYONE’S CROWDED AT THE BAR. Champagne corks are popping. POP POP POP.  111. WELLS (V.O.) (CONT’D) And everyone else has turned back. And now he’s alone. And it’s burning hot. And there is no water... And ON THE CASINO FLOOR Wells is PLAYING ROULETTE. The WH IS SPINNING. STACKS OF MONEY are moving. SHOW GIRLS ARE FLOCKING. Then IT’S EVEN LATER. WELLS IS SPORTING DRINKS ALL AROUND Champagne. POP POP POP.

It’s out there... It’s out there... It’s out there... TIGHTER ON THE FACE OF KENNY WELLS as he sits back at his table, accepting the congratulations of his friends. As p call his name and cheer and FLASHBULBS POP -- POP POP POP BACK AT THE PODIUM. Tight on Wells as he takes in all of listening faces. WELLS (CONT’D) And it doesn’t matter whether he finds it or not. It doesn’t matter. That’s a prospector. He basks in it, the words vibrating for everyone in the r
Tracking across the detritus of a huge night to find Well bed, sound asleep. The phone starts to RING -- Wells does move. Then finally he moans, rolls toward the phone --

Hello..? What..? What? Wells is instantly awake. Hear the INDONESIAN FOREMAN say something FRANTIC over the and over-- WELLS (CONT’D) I’m sorry I can’t understand you. No go? I don’t understand. Slowly. Speak more slowly.

head_text.subj: PHONE THE SIZE OF A SUITCASE.

text: (slowly) No gold. There is NO GOLD. The window behind Wells reveals sun just catching the pea flaming morning gold. Wells grips the phone like a lifeli
A mob scene outside. As Wells pulls up in his car, the cr converges on him. He can barely get his car door open. He squeezes out and pushes through the furious crowd --

I don’t know any more than you do right now! ...-But nobody’s hearing him -- PEOPLE shout out: “You fu thief!" “I'm gonna kill you!" “Where's our money?!" WELLS (CONT’D) I will get to the bottom of this! I promise! Suddenly, out of nowhere -- A FIST -- WHAM -- right acros Wells's face! It staggers him. The crowd lets out a roar approval. This is getting real ugly, real fast. A PAIR OF HANDS GRABS WELLS. He turns, panic in his eyes but it’s Connie Wright. Bobby Burns is with him. They pul Wells through the mob to the building’s side entrance.
Total shit storm, Kenny. Wells is still dazed.
I know... I know... They fight the last few feet to the door and as they forc their way inside, WE FOLLOW THEM...
They’re out of breath, adrenaline pumping. Wells turns to face his friends’ haunted expressions...
What happened? How did this happen?
The independent assayer... they couldn’t reproduce Mike’s findings.  113. Wells trying to take it in.
There’s no gold, Kenny. There’s no goddamn gold. There never was.
That’s not possible.
CNN NEWS CENTER -- A professorial looking MINING EXPERT explains to a NEWS ANCHOR...

It’s called “salting” and it literally means, when someone sprinkles gold dust into a sample of rock, like you'd add salt to a steak. GOLD DUST -- pours onto a DIGITAL SCALE. MINING EXPERT (CONT’D) By all appearances, Washoe’s security protocols were iron-clad. But if the person administering security is fraudulent, the system breaks down. Then, the gold dust sprinkles into a GROUND SAMPLE OF ROC MINING EXPERT (CONT’D) ...It’s the oldest trick in the book.
“Oldest trick in the book.” And yet major mining corporations, investment banks, auditors, everyone was fooled.
We weren’t fooled; we didn’t look. TIGHT ON: A MAGNIFIED IMAGE -- TWO GOLD SAMPLES, side by side. The one on the LEFT has smoothly rounded edges; the on the RIGHT is angular and jagged.

The image on the left is the type of gold found in the Washoe samples. This is river gold - notice how the edges are rounded, worn smooth by the erosion of the water. WE PULL BACK to --  114. A FINANCIAL SHOW -- The GEOLOGIST is seated across from a Cramer-type financial HOST. GEOLOGIST (CONT’D) ...What we should have found is flake gold - the sample on the right, pulled directly from the rock, rough edged and angular. The Host is nearly apoplectic --
That seems like a pretty big freakin’ detail to overlook!
It’s a big detail. But you have to understand, everything else about the Washoe samples was right...
..-But the gold was wrong! It’s right there, that’s what you’re saying?!
Yes.
The guys are hard at work, going over financial documents Wells is on a phone at the center of it all --
(into phone) Acosta? Mike Acosta? No. Yes, I do mind waiting -- Did he or did he not come to the Kalimantan? Bobby Burns approaches Wells. Burns looks gut-punched.

The New York Stock Exchange just suspended trading. They’re taking Washoe off the board. Washoe is done, finished. Wells sinks back in his chair. slowly hangs up the phone. The news seems to take whateve he’s got left out of him. A long silent moment. There’s nothing more to say, but Bu just stands there. He looks in shock, like he’s had his s ripped out. Wells looks up at him...  115.
You sold some, right? Put something away? Burns hesitates before answering...
Yeah... Of course. You? Wells nods halfheartedly. It’s clear neither sold a damn thing.
Bobby?... Burns can’t meet Wells's eyes. WELLS (CONT’D) Goddammit, Bobby! I told you to sell some.
I thought...I thought... it was just going to keep going up. Wells is genuinely distressed. And then Burns looks up -- eyes are damp, on the verge of crying. He can barely spea
Kenny, did you know, Did you know, Kenny? It’s like a blow to the heart.
What? Did I know? I can’t believe you would ask me that. Burns looks absolutely crushed. WELLS (CONT’D) I’ll take care of you, Bobby. Connie rushes in carrying a sheath of PAPERS.
Kenny... Burns’ expression hardens -- fists clenched like he’s gon punch Wells.
I don’t want you to take care of me! I want you to leave me the hell alone!  116. Burns walks away, a busted man. Wells turns to Connie. On look and he knows this is big.
What?
I don’t even know how to say this -- He dumps the papers on Wells's desk.
Look. Wells reads. It doesn’t take him long to understand. He t a glass at the wall. It shatters.
Connie answers Stanton’s questioning look.
Acosta was dumping stock. Shell companies. Banks in the Philippines, the Azores. Multiple layers. All off- shore.
How much?
Get ready for it... 164 million.
I don’t believe it.
Son of a bitch! What do we do? Kenny?

There’s gotta be an explanation. We gotta find Mike! AT THAT MOMENT, they hear TIRES SCREECHING, CAR DOORS SLAMMING. And look outside. DOZENS OF AGENTS rolling up, familiar blue jackets with the white lettering -- FBI. He them entering. Then, a BULLHORN:

This is the FBI! Step away from your desks! Take two big steps away from your desks. Do not touch anything!  117. MONTAGE of FBI raid. Floor by floor. They arrive at Wells office. Connie and Stanton in the middle of the room, fro Wells at the window. Below, he sees the SPECIAL AGENT IN CHARGE step out of a car, already giving quiet orders -- It’s JENNINGS. Who looks up. Sees Wells at the window. Wells looks at hi
Sitting with ROGER MUDD is MARK HANCOCK, chairman of Newp Holdings. Hancock as clean as snow as he rewrites history

We suspected there were problems early on, which is why we decided not to pursue the joint venture Washoe offered us. We got as many of our investors out of Washoe as fast as possible. An insert PHOTO of Kenny Wells and Mike Acosta appears.
You made a lot of money. I mean before the walls came tumbling down. Hancock doesn't want to talk about that. ROGER MUDD (CONT’D) And how much money was lost in the fraud? That we know of.
Billions. Large institutional investors lost billions of dollars.
So one, or maybe both of them, two outsiders took everybody on Wall Street for a ride.
Yes, it really looks like they did.
And Acosta has vanished.
With hundreds of millions of dollars.  118.

Kenny Wells has consistently maintained his innocence, that he was duped along with everyone else. Given that, what do you make of this? He picks up a copy of NEWSWEEK MAGAZINE -- Kenny Wells on cover. Mudd reads the caption out loud: ROGER MUDD (CONT’D) “Kenny Wells - Fool or Mastermind?" ».-Care to comment? Off Hancock, maybe for the first time, he’s at a loss...
That is a very good question, Roger.
A MONTAGE of time passing. Wells in the suite on the phon Wells at an increasingly empty Washoe headquarters. Wells increasingly desperate, then finally hopeless.
Wells stands on the steps in front of the building, a hun MICROPHONES and CAMERAS in his face. NEWS VANS jam the sidewalk. A mob of ANGRY PROTESTORS held at bay by POLICE

Mike Acosta was my friend and partner and he betrayed me. I had no knowledge of the deception he perpetrated. As CEO of this company, it was my job to know. I take full responsibility for my failure in this regard and I apologize sincerely to those who have lost their investments. Wherever you are, Mike, it’s time to come in. Tell what happened... Mike --? He can’t go on. Finally, he chokes out -- WELLS (CONT’D) That’s all I have to say at this time. The assembled reporters shout out a flurry of questions a Wells's back as he leaves. They pursue him. Surrounding h car. Trying to stop him from pulling out.  119. EXT. HARRAH’S HOTEL AND CASINO - RENO - DAY
Wells pulls in. Crowds out front waiting for him. INT. HARRAH’S HOTEL AND CASINO - RENO - DAY
Angry FRONT DESK GUY trying to talk about the bill.
Mr. Wells, when exactly will you be departing? People hearing his name. Crowds turning. Pouring in.
The doors closing out the faces of angry, shouting people Wells just shuts his eyes and rides in blessed silence. DING.
Wells checks the hallway both directions. AT THE “PROSPECTOR SUITE” Checks hall again. Uses his key to open the door.
Wells entering, motoring toward the bar, freezes. Finds:
Waiting for him like executioners on execution day. A beat.
Do I need a lawyer?

Do you need a lawyer? A moment between poker players. Then Wells shakes his hea JENNINGS (CONT’D) Right answer. Jennings posts two guards outside the door. Sets the tape recorder on the table. Wells at the bar searching, findin stashed bottle.  120.
.«.--Sure I can’t pour you one?
No, thanks. I’m working.
All the more reason.
Wells, sit down. We’ve got a lot to cover... The same exchange that started the film. Time has caught with Kenny Wells’ storytelling.
The Golden Pickaxe STATUE catching morning sun...
The Sierra Nevada out the windows. It’s fall.
Wells facing Jennings, listening.
I think it’s pretty unlikely we'll ever see your partner again.
Wait, what do you mean? You're not telling me something. What happened to Mike?
A lot of very powerful people are very angry at Michael Acosta.
What happened! ? Jennings searches Wells's face again for a trace of the disingenuous.
What happened? Yes. That’s what we’re trying to put together. (MORE)

Seventeen billion dollars of value disappeared overnight. That is certain. What else? Michael Acosta waves goodbye to you in the ballroom downstairs -- ta-ta -- goes back to Indonesia on a jet chartered with Washoe funds, and then he does his disappearing act. This you know... Off Wells -- PRE-LAP: The sound of HELICOPTER ROTORS, growing louder. Deafening
A helicopter chops at the morning air -- flying in low ov the lush jungle as the sun is about to rise.
First, he’s locked out of the assay lab in Kalimantan by The Minister of the Interior. So he goes back to Jakarta.
Acosta emerges from a plane and walks down the gangway st
Where he is immediately detained by Indonesian Military. Waiting for him at the bottom are INDONESIAN SOLDIERS.
(subtitled) This way Mr. Acosta.
And they hold him while they try to reproduce for themselves the lab results claimed by Washoe.
Acosta watching men march in formation through a doorway.
Which of course they are unable to do.  122.
Jennings takes his time. He’s enjoying this a little.
And at this point either he’s being moved to an actual prison, or he’s bribed one of the officers. Either way, he’s on a military helicopter.
Acosta sits in the hold of the chopper, two soldiers acro from him, a pilot and another SOLDIER up front, all armed
They fly north loosely tracking the Kensana river. The chopper arcs in, following the river’s course. Acosta stares out, far into the distance, taking in the breathtaking beauty.

Do not underestimate the Suharto family. They are gangsters whose turf is a nation of 100 million. Acosta in the back of the chopper. He’s got a six-pack of Tuborg Gold in cans. He cracks one, holds the others out the soldiers, who decline. He drains the beer. He looks d at the river as it passes far below, flashing gold in the sunlight, a snaking golden river, golden dream -- Hands suddenly undo his harness. An involuntary breath. T smile creeps onto his face. Acosta now at the open hatch door of the chopper. Tighter his eyes taking it in. He’s coming home.

head_text.subj: IN SILENCE MIKE ACOSTA FALLS FROM THE HELICOPTER

text: Falling and falling and falling toward canpoy and water -  123.

A thousand feet up, over the Kensana, Mike Acosta takes a header. ON THE PILOT -- as he turns and looks back and sees the E SEAT, the soldiers buckling back in. He turns back around ACOSTA POV of ONRUSHING RIVER. CLOSER AND CLOSER AND THEN
Wells is on the edge of his seat, eyes red from lack of s booze, cigarette smoke. He’s shaken up by the news. He do want to believe it.

No way. No fucking way. Mike was too good, too savvy. He had to be planning this. He knows what they do to you for salting. What you think they’d do. He faked it. Or he paid just to have the story out. (desperate) 164 million goes a long way in Indonesia...
(beat) They found a body.
Are you sure it’s him?

I’m not sure of anything, except Mike Acosta traded water filters for river gold, but now the Indonesian government has gone unusually quiet on the subject and seems to have, publicly at least, lost all interest in finding Michael Acosta.

THE CRANE SHOT of the INDONESIAN MILITARY and DAYAK in se circle around the SPLAYED BODY. One of the soldiers breaks ranks and moves forward, kneel by the body. What he sees there sickens him --  124.

Hands and face were eaten away. Probably by wild pigs. BANG. All heads whirl. The BIG SNAKE FALLS. Floats down r The soldier finds the wallet, flips it open, checks the I And this time we see the name -- MICHAEL ACOSTA. And a picture of MIKE ACOSTA, smiling.
There was an autopsy, corroborating the identity with dental records from Boston.
Jennings produces documents with a sort of bemused skepti Autopsy. Photos of a pig-eaten body. Affidavit of cremati

Then they sealed the report, cremated the remains. Interestingly Danny Suharto dumped a lot of stock as well. So the Suhartos are even richer, Mike Acosta is ostensibly dead and buried, a hundred sixty four million is still missing, and the question I’m left with is whether or not you were in on it? Wells takes a moment. Slowly shakes his head. Sad.
I can’t believe it.
Can't believe what? Wells eyes well up. He rubs at them, making them even red He lights a cig to cover the emotions.
...Everyone in the business had written him off, called his theories crap, and he couldn’t let that be the last word on him.
You talking about Acosta or yourself? Wells ignores that.  125.

We were running out of money and I was sick with Malaria, I think that’s when the salting started. Mike was sure he was right, the gold was there, but he needed to buy us more time to find it. I don’t think he set out to swindle anyone, but by the time he realized he was wrong and there was no gold, he was in too deep. I honestly think he just didn’t want to let me down. And I was fooled just like everybody else. A pregnant beat. Levine, Jennings’ underling, leans down. saying something that is mostly muffled... “Either world’ biggest fool or...”
..-he’s not telling the truth --

The truth!? The only truth here is that when everyone’s getting rich nobody gives a shit about the truth. All anyone had to do was look. Open their eyes. The gold was wrong. The find was too good. Red flags everywhere, but no one looked, because no one wanted to know. Not me, not you, not anyone. What we all wanted was to believe. Why? Because we were making so much money. Jennings looks over at Banks and Levine. That landed.

(to his coworkers) Mark, Eric, sit down please. Jennings checks the cassette on the tape recorder. And wh addresses his questions to Wells we can feel it’s all com down to this. JENNINGS (CONT’D) Were you aware that Mike Acosta was salting the Washoe core samples?
No!
You had no knowledge Mike Acosta was perpetrating a fraud?  126.
No. I thought I’d won the lottery.
You were not in collusion with Mike Acosta on the Kensana gold strike?
No.
Did you profit from the Kensana fraud?
You know I didn’t. I can’t pay the hotel bill. Hell, I can’t even get the minibar.
Did anyone close to you profit?
No.
You have gained nothing?

My friends lost money, my neighbors lost money, but I lost everything. Because, the real truth is... I never cared much about money. I cared about gold. It’s different, Jennings. It’s different. Jennings, Banks, and Levine walk away and confer. It’s cl they’re having a difficult time reaching a quorum. Wells turns and looks at the mountains. And then Jennings crosses back.

(into tape recorder) End of deposition, 6:45 AM, Seventeen, October, 1988, conducted by Paul K. Jennings - Special Agent In Charge, Federal Bureau of Investigation, District of Nevada, Reno. He presses stop on the recorder. Closes his notes. He and Wells look at each other a long moment. JENNINGS (CONT’D) You're free to go, Mr. Wells.  127. Wells seems like he wasn’t expecting this and maybe almos like he was past caring about it.
Look at that, somebody believes me.
I wouldn’t go overboard. In fact, I wouldn’t leave the state. Wouldn’t start buying new stuff or chartering any more jets.
I gotta sneak out of here without the front desk guy seeing me. You picking up that tab?
It’s been quite a whirlwind, hasn’t it, Mr. Wells? Wells has no fucking idea how to even begin to answer tha one. As the coworkers leave --
Good luck, Mr. Wells
We'll be keeping an eye out for you. Jennings starts to leave, then pauses --

What are you going to do now, Wells? And as we push in on Wells, we can see deep in his eyes t beginnings of a plan... EXT. PARKING LOT - HARRAH’S HOTEL AND CASINO - MORNING Wells looks back at the hotel. He sees two red-tailed haw perched on a balcony rail. They drop in unison and then r on a warm draft. Wells watches them rise and rise.

Is placed on the passenger seat of his car. Wells smoking Driving. Flicks ashes at the ashtray, misses by a mile.  128. Through the glass, a familiar, neater house appears. EXT. KAY’S HOUSE - DAY He pulls into the driveway of Kay’s house. The car shuts He gathers himself. Picks up the rose. Gets out of the ca Hart Hubbard, pruning a bush, stops snipping.
Kenny, I’m still worried about that mulberry over the back fence. An old Mulberry tree grows over the shared fence. Wells doesn’t need to look.
I know. Good to see you, Hart.
Good to see you too, Kenny. He’s at the door. He takes a breath and knocks. After a w he hears footsteps. Then the door opens. Revealing KAY. S looks at the single flower. At Wells.
Can I come in? Kay considers a beat longer than is comfortable, then ste aside to let him in.
Wells sees the pool has been fixed and filled. It sparkle Wells sitting at the dinette looking at Kay. She looks at A golden light shines through new curtains above the sink
I made curtains.
The house looks great. And so do you. Kay puts the flower in a small vase. She puts two coffee on the dinette. She looks at him a moment then shakes her head. Wells takes a cup of coffee.
I called up Carl.  129.
You called Carl? (beat) What'd he say?
I think he was surprised to hear from me. He’ll see me next week. No promises.
Wait, you really called him?

(beat) No... Not yet. But I’m going to. She starts to laugh. He starts to laugh. He reaches out h hand to hold hers across the table. They look at each oth WELLS (CONT’D) Goddamn. And then they laugh at the absurdity of it all, of life, trying to make sense of any of it.

Oh, some stuff came for you. Some mail. She goes and finds a grocery bag of stuff that’s come for He dumps it on the table, searching past catalogues and t share opportunities, until he finds what he’s looking for

Thin and light blue with PAR AVION stamped on it. Wells looks at it. He looks at Kay. Then he takes out a s pocket knife, uses the short blade to slice it open. He extracts... an old napkin. THE NAPKIN. The one he and Acosta signed in the jungle. He unfolds it He reads: Prove ‘em all wrong. “50-50" Whatever it takes...  130. Followed by two faded signatures: Kenny Wells & Mike Acos He stares at Mike’s signature a long moment, remembering.
What? What is it?
In his name, at THE FIRST BANK OF GIBRALTAR, exactly half Acosta sold, fifty percent. He looks up at Kay mysteriously. And he smiles.
